column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Causalstatements|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Ecosystem|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Focalpoint|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Locationofstudy|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Mainhypothesisandcorrespondingresults|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Method|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Reccomendationsandsuggestions|
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Timeperiodofstudy|

#Text=Response of ectomycorrhizal fungi to full and selective removal of an invasive tree in riparian woodland\rDavid C Banuelas,�Neil C Shah,�Jennifer E Perez,�Samantha A Bellier-Igasaki,�Emily McGauley,�Amanda C Swanson,�Alys Arenas,�Kathleen K Treseder\rFirst published: 04 June 2024\r�\rhttps://doi.org/10.1111/rec.14204\rAuthor contributions: DCB, KKT conceived the study design and developed the manuscript; AS, AA provided early feedback to the study design and manuscript; all remaining authors conducted field work and/or molecular sequencing.
#Text=Coordinating Editor: Rebecca Brown\rSECTIONS\rPDF\rTOOLS\r�\rSHARE\rAbstract.
#Text=The Brazilian pepper tree (Schinus terebinthifolius) is an invasive species that requires significant disturbance to eradicate.
#Text=Previous studies have identified associations between the Brazilian pepper tree and ectomycorrhizal fungi (EMF).
#Text=However, limited research has explored the connection between disturbance from removal and the effect on EMF.
#Text=This study investigated the sensitivity of EMF and the broader fungal community to the full and selective removal of the Brazilian pepper tree.

#Text=During the selective removal of Brazilian pepper tree, we examined the mycorrhizal community of the Arroyo willow (Salix lasiolepis) to assess the influence of the restoration disturbance on native species.
#Text=We used ITS2 sequencing to identify the EMF present during the restoration.
#Text=Our expectation was that both removal efforts would reduce the presence of EMF.
#Text=Contrary to our predictions, full removal increased EMF richness and relative abundance in the soil.
#Text=As anticipated, selective removal reduced the richness and relative abundance of EMF associated with soil.
#Text=Selective removal led to a decrease in the richness of EMF in arroyo willow roots with no effect on relative abundance.
#Text=Moreover, fungal community composition in soil and roots shifted significantly during selective and full removal.
#Text=However, the community composition of EMF, specifically, remained constant across treatment types.
#Text=During full removal efforts, the application of organic soil amendments may have contributed to the increase in the diversity and relative abundance of EMF.
#Text=Selective removal will require additional measures, such as soil amendments, to curtail the loss of EMF.

#Text=Implications for Practice\r* Despite minimal disturbances to native arroyo willows during the selective removal of the Brazilian pepper tree, the diversity of ectomycorrhizal fungi (EMF) declined.\r* While the application of a commercial inoculum was deployed after the full removal of the Brazilian pepper tree, the commercial mycorrhizal species were not indicated in our sequences.\r* Following the restoration of riparian communities in Southern California,�Geopora� spp could be used as a reference inoculum to mitigate the loss of EMF.
#Text=Introduction.

#Text=Brazilian pepper tree (Schinus terebinthifolius�Raddi) is a cosmopolitan invasive tree from Brazil that is difficult to eradicate without substantial disturbance to soils (Dalrymple et al�2003; Smith et al�2011).
#Text=In North America, the Brazilian pepper tree can harbor a higher diversity of mycorrhizal fungi than do native species (Dawkins & Esiobu�2017; Gomes et al�2018).
#Text=Mycorrhizal fungi are important in restoration since they typically improve the growth and nutrient content of their host plants (Hoeksema et al�2010; Maltz & Treseder�2015).
#Text=They colonize plant roots and grow hyphae into the soil to scavenge for nutrients (Smith & Read�2008).
#Text=They then transfer a portion of the nutrients to their host plant (Smith & Read�2008).
#Text=In exchange, the host plant provides carbohydrates to the mycorrhizal partner (Smith & Read�2008).
#Text=The greater diversity of mycorrhizal fungi benefits the Brazilian pepper tree by increasing access to nutrients (Dawkins & Esiobu�2017).
#Text=Additionally, the Brazilian pepper tree produces allelochemicals that can decrease native plant growth (Dawkins et al�2022).
#Text=The Brazilian pepper tree is associated with arbuscular mycorrhizal fungi (AMF) and ectomycorrhizal fungi (EMF; Dawkins & Esiobu�2017).

#Text=While AMF has been shown to respond positively to the removal of the Brazilian pepper tree (Aziz et al�1995), the effect of invasive removal on the EMF partners of native species is less understood.

#Text=In Southern California, the native species Arroyo willow (Salix lasiolepis�Benth.) competes directly with Brazilian pepper tree in riparian communities and is dual mycorrhizal (i.e. harbors EMF and AMF; Mullens & Gerry�2006; Teste et al�2020).
#Text=There is a need for studies of EMF responses to the removal of Brazilian pepper tree and the potential consequences for restoration of native plants like Arroyo willow (Dawkins & Esiobu�2017).

#Text=The Brazilian pepper tree was introduced to North America in 1898, becoming a widespread ornamental species in Southern California during the nineteenth century (Pincetl et al�2013; Banuelas et al�2019).

#Text=By the 1980s, the Brazilian pepper tree had severely invaded the Upper Newport Bay Ecological Reserve ( Upper Newport Bay�) and adjacent habitat preserves in Southern California (OC Archives�2023).

#Text=The invasion prevented the establishment of willow (Salix� spp) thickets, which support the nesting of the federally endangered Least Bell's Vireo (Vireo bellii pusillus) in Upper Newport Bay (Pohl�2016).
#Text=In response to widespread invasions in Northern and Southern California, the State of California designated the Brazilian pepper tree as invasive in 2000 (Bossard et al�2006).
#Text=Since then, land managers in the Upper Newport Bay have used selective removal of the Brazilian pepper tree to preserve native willows (Pohl�2016).
#Text=When native willows are absent, full removal is deployed (Pohl�2016).
#Text=The decision to use mechanical removal among other strategies in the Upper Newport Bay was informed by the feasibility of alternative methods used in Florida (Bossard et al�2006).
#Text=Controlling the invasive Brazilian pepper tree has proven challenging due to its resistance to removal.
#Text=Numerous restoration efforts have been attempted.
#Text=Controlled burns are inadvisable, since they can facilitate the spread of the Brazilian pepper tree (Stevens & Beckage�2009).
#Text=Although chemical controls have been effective, they require applications to the cambium and are not always feasible (Enloe et al�2021).
#Text=In 2019, biological controls were introduced in Florida, and their long-term impact will be assessed in the coming decades (Prade et al�2022).
#Text=The most efficient method is mechanical removal, though it is expensive and can take several decades to complete (Smith et al�2011; Asmelash et al�2016; Dawkins & Esiobu�2016).

#Text=In other ecosystems, the application of prescribed burns, herbicide, and biological treatments led to varying outcomes for mycorrhizal fungi (DeSandoli et al�2016; Weidlich et al�2020; Roche et al�2021).

#Text=In cases where removing invasive species reduces the abundance of mycorrhizal fungi used by native species, adding mycorrhizal inoculum associated with natives can mitigate these negative effects (Rowe et al�2007; Phillips et al�2020; Duell et al�2022).
#Text=Since each restoration effort may yield different outcomes, it is crucial to conduct studies that characterize the fungal community after the removal of the Brazilian pepper tree.
#Text=These studies can inform restoration strategies that are effective and sustainable.
#Text=We tested two hypotheses addressing how mycorrhizal fungi is affected by the full and selective removal of the Brazilian pepper tree in Big Canyon Nature Park ( Big Canyon�).
#Text=We first posited that the relative abundance and diversity of mycorrhizal fungi would decrease owing to the disturbance caused by full and selective removal (Hypothesis 1).

#Text=We also anticipated significant shifts in the community composition of mycorrhizal fungi, as well as the overall fungal community, for both types of removal, because only a subset of fungi can tolerate the disturbance generated by plant removal (Hypothesis 2).
#Text=Methods.
#Text=Site Description.
#Text=We tested our hypotheses at Big Canyon (lat 33degreesN, long 117degreesW), which experiences a Mediterranean climate.
#Text=The locale receives an average of 279  mm of rainfall each year, with a mean annual temperature of 19.9degreesC (WRCC�2023).
#Text=The typical dry season runs from May through October, when the monthly rainfall is less than 20  mm.
#Text=The wet season extends from November to April, when the average rainfall ranges between 23 and 42  mm each month.
#Text=The dominant soil type is Sorrento loam, on 2_9% slopes (NCRS�2023).
#Text=The main parcel of Big Canyon comprises 15.5  ha owned by the City of Newport Beach ( Newport Beach�;  Fig�1).
#Text=Additionally, Big Canyon Creek drains into the Upper Newport Bay, which is managed by the California Department of Fish and Wildlife (CDFW).
#Text=The Kizh, Tongva, and Acjachemen Nations are the traditional stewards of the region and continue to advise management decisions in the Upper Newport Bay (McCawley�1996).
#Text=Figure 1\r \rThe boundary and project area of the Big Canyon Nature Park.
#Text=The distribution of trees used in our study is represented by green or magenta circles along with red, blue, or green polygons denoting restoration types.
#Text=Big Canyon is part of a large habitat reserve referred to as the Upper Newport Bay, located in Southern California.
#Text=Restoration Approach\rIn partnership with Newport Beach and CDFW, the Newport Bay Conservancy led the Big Canyon restoration project.
#Text=The work spanned October 2020 through January 2021.
#Text=In 2020, restoration practitioners removed 6.3  ha of Brazilian Pepper tree stands from Big Canyon using two approaches: full and selective removal ( Fig�1).
#Text=In full removal, to eliminate all Brazilian pepper tree roots, clearing and grubbing were deployed, followed by the application of a commercial inoculum consisting of AMF and EMF.
#Text=In selective removal, clearing and grubbing were used sparingly to avoid damage to native willows.
#Text=We did not add inoculum following selective removal to avoid disturbing the native willows.

#Text=As commercial applications seldom increase the presence of mycorrhizal fungi (Maltz & Treseder�2015), we did not necessarily expect the inoculum to increase the mycorrhizal colonization in Big Canyon.
#Text=Selective Removal\rTo safeguard established Arroyo willows, 0.7  ha were designated for selective removal (see  Fig�1).
#Text=To minimize disturbance to the arroyo willow during the selective removal, excavator activity was limited.
#Text=This approach is more costly than full removal and was therefore used on a smaller area.
#Text=The selective removal also ensured that mature willows neighbored the young willows to be planted in the full removal area.
#Text=Unlike the full removal, the selective approach left the topsoil beneath willows intact.
#Text=Due to a lack of access, the organic soil amendment and commercial inoculum was not applied beneath the canopy of willows.
#Text=Full Removal\rThe entire 5.6  ha of dense Brazilian pepper tree woodland was targeted for full removal ( Fig�2A�&�2B).
#Text=Because the Brazilian pepper tree can resprout from cut stumps, the removal process was conducted in two phases.
#Text=Initially, chainsaw crews cleared all vegetation by removing the canopy and tree trunks ( Fig�2C�&�2D).
#Text=To remove the seedbank, the top 5  cm of topsoil was disposed offsite along with all leaf litter and woody biomass.
#Text=Subsequently, an excavator (backhoe) removed the root biomass (grubbing) along with the top 60  cm of topsoil.
#Text=Following the stockpiling of topsoil, the Big Canyon Creek was recontoured to support a restored riparian corridor, which included the outplanting of willow cuttings.
#Text=Figure 2\r \rProgress of Brazilian pepper tree removal.
#Text=Three stages are shown: Before removal (A & B), 60% completion (C & D), and after removal (E & F).
#Text=Red polygon  =  full removal restoration.
#Text=Blue polygon  =  selective removal restoration.
#Text=Green polygon  =  restored riparian corridor.
#Text=The stockpiled soil was mixed with an organic amendment on site and applied evenly through the full removal area by tilling or raking.

#Text=The organic soils amendment consisted of humic acid with silicon (BioAg's Humisolve-ION14TM; humic acid 50%, soluble silicon 2%), chitin (Neptune Harvest's brand  Crab Shell 2_3_0�; 5% nitrogen, 3% phosphate, 17% calcium, and 1% magnesium) and vermicompost (Earthworm Soil Factory's Garden Blend; 5% worm casting, 95% compost; ESA�2020).
#Text=The soil amendment included nutrients and a commercial inoculum manufactured by Fungi Perfecti LLC (MycoGrow Soluble; ESA�2020).
#Text=The inoculum included nine AMF and 10 EMF species, with no bacterial species or non-mycorrhizal fungi reported (Table�S1).
#Text=Following full removal, arroyo willows were outplanted in the restored riparian corridor in January 2021 ( Fig�1; Pohl�2016).
#Text=The willow outplanting was cultivated from cuttings and completed prior to soil collections in February 2021.
#Text=Sampling Design\rBefore removal began, we collected 30 soil samples from the full removal area and 30 from the selective removal area ( Fig�1).
#Text=In the full removal zone, the soil samples were gathered within the proposed restored riparian corridor.
#Text=There, Brazilian pepper tree cover exceeded 90% before removal.
#Text=To establish the sampling locations within the riparian corridor, we used the Random Point Generator Tool in ArcGIS Pro (2.1.0), identifying 30 random points ( Fig�1).
#Text=Similarly, we selected 30 random points within the selective removal area, where the native cover was less than 30%.
#Text=We collected 10 soil samples from each of the three existing willow groves ( Fig�1).
#Text=After removal, we revisited the same locations to repeat the sampling process.
#Text=Sample Collection\rSoil samples were collected in the full and selective removal areas between August 28th and September 3rd, 2020.
#Text=After the removal of the Brazilian pepper tree was completed in January 2021, a second set of soil samples was collected from February 5th to 9th, 2021.

#Text=The first collection coincided with the end of the Arroyo willows' growing season in the fall, and the second collection occurred during their flowering period, which typically begins in mid-January (Baldwin & Goldman�2012).

#Text=The second collection of soil beneath Arroyo willows, occurred during the outset of the flowering season to avoid the confounding effects of seasonality (M�hlmann & Peintner�2008; Hrynkiewicz et al�2015).
#Text=We also examined roots from the soil cores, targeting the roots of the arroyo willow following selective removal.
#Text=While roots of the Brazilian pepper tree were collected prior to full removal efforts, we omitted them from DNA sequencing since roots were entirely removed following removal efforts.
#Text=Soil samples were collected approximately 0.2_0.5  m from the dripline of the nearest target tree to the random sampling point.
#Text=We collected soil cores with a bulb planter (Ames Hand Bulb Planter) with a diameter of 10  cm and a depth of 10  cm.
#Text=To prevent the spread of pathogens, a 70% ethanol alcohol solution was used to sterilize the bulb planter between sites.
#Text=Each soil core was placed in a sterile Whirl-Pak bag and kept on ice during the fieldwork.
#Text=Within 6  hours of collection each day, the soil samples were stored at   20degreesC in our laboratory at the University of California, Irvine (UCI).
#Text=In total, we recovered 120 soil samples (30 samples      2 removal treatments      2 time points).
#Text=Root Extraction\rFirst, we extracted the roots from the soil.
#Text=Each sample was passed through a 10  mm sieve.
#Text=All samples were sieved and extracted on the same day and then stored at   20degreesC.
#Text=We collected fine roots (<2  mm diameter) of the target species from the sieve.
#Text=We used color and morphology to distinguish Brazilian pepper tree roots from Arroyo willow, following Ruas et al (2011).
#Text=At all sampling locations, we collected soil cores from monocultures where the Brazilian pepper tree or the arroyo willow was the only plant species present.
#Text=This way, we avoided roots from other trees.
#Text=We then rinsed the roots with deionized water three times.
#Text=The roots were kept on ice until DNA extraction, which occurred on the same day.

#Text=Since, by design, Brazilian pepper tree roots were not present in our post-removal samples from the full removal area, we only processed arroyo willow roots prior to and following selective removal.

#Text=Consequently, we obtained 30 samples of Brazilian pepper tree roots (30 samples      1 time point) and 60 samples of arroyo willow roots (3 groves      10 samples      2 time points), resulting in a total of 90 root samples.
#Text=DNA Sequencing\rWe used the DNeasy PowerSoil Pro Kit (Qiagen, Redwood City, CA, U.S.A.) to extract DNA from 250  mg of each soil sample, following the manufacturer's instructions.
#Text=For the root samples, we used the DNeasy Plant Pro Kit (Qiagen, Redwood City, CA, U.S.A.) and extracted DNA from 50  mg of roots.

#Text=For the roots, we followed a modified lysing step, where the FastPrep-24 (two 60  seconds cycles at 6  m/second; MP Biomedicals, LLC, Solon, OH, U.S.A.) was used with the DNeasy Plant Pro Kit (Gonzalez Mateu et al�2020).
#Text=To target the fungal DNA in both soil and root samples, we employed a two-step Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) approach, focusing on the ITS2 region.
#Text=In the first PCR, we amplified the DNA using the fITS7 (5   GTGARTCATCGAATCTTTG) and ITS4 (TCCTCCGCTTATTGATATGC-3  ) primers with Illumina Nextera Adapters.
#Text=The PCR parameters of Lekberg et al (2018) were used.
#Text=Successful amplification at approximately 420 base pairs was confirmed through gel electrophoresis after the first PCR.
#Text=Nineteen samples failed to amplify and were not included in the second PCR.

#Text=The samples that were amplified correctly in the first PCR were used for the second PCR, where dual-indexed barcodes were attached at an annealing temperature of 60degreesC, following the method described by Lekberg et al (2018).
#Text=Gel electrophoresis was performed to verify the successful amplification of the second PCR.
#Text=After the final clean-up with Ampure XP beads (Beckman Coulter, Brea, CA, U.S.A.), the amplicon library was pooled based on gel intensity (1, 2, or 3    L).

#Text=The sequencing of the library was conducted at the Genomics Research and Technology Hub (GRT Hub) at UCI (https://ghtf.biochem.uci.edu/; Irvine, CA, U.S.A.) using the Illumina MiSeq platform (Illumina Inc., San Diego, CA, U.S.A.) with 2      300  bp paired-end (PE) reads.
#Text=The raw sequences are available to the public through NCBI's Sequences Read Archive under the accession number PRJNA1083097.
#Text=Bioinformatics\rThe demultiplexed sequences were pre-processed using AMPtk software v1.5.4 (Palmer et al�2018).
#Text=After concatenating all PE reads, the demultiplexed files were clustered into operational taxonomic units (OTUs) with a 97% similarity cutoff.
#Text=This level of similarity allows for taxonomic resolution at approximately the species level (K�ljalg et al�2013).
#Text=The sequences were filtered using default parameters, and taxonomy was assigned using the UNITE database (K�ljalg et al�2005).
#Text=All non-fungal sequences were removed.
#Text=Where possible, trophic modes were assigned to the OTUs using the FUNGuild database provided by AMPtk (Nguyen et al�2016).
#Text=To calculate the relative abundances of EMF, the OTU counts were summed and divided by the total OTU count for each sample.
#Text=The result was multiplied by 100 to express the relative abundance as a percentage.
#Text=Due to the biased nature of the IT2 primers used, we elected to focus our efforts on EMF (Lekberg et al�2018), omitting AMF from statistical analysis.
#Text=Statistical Analysis\rAll statistical analyses were performed using R Studio 4.1.2 (RStudio Team�2021).
#Text=Statistical analyses were performed separately for full versus selective removal since the two approaches were not directly comparable.
#Text=A Shapiro�Wilk test from the  stats� package was used to assess normality (RStudio Team�2021).
#Text=We were unable to transform much of our data to meet assumptions of normality.
#Text=Thus, we applied a non-parametric Wilcoxon rank sum test to assess the differences in the distribution of species richness and relative abundance.
#Text=Additionally, we used a one-sided test, aligning with our prediction that both removal efforts would facilitate a decline in the richness and relative abundance of EMF.
#Text=For all tests, effects were considered significant when�p�less than 0.05 and were accompanied by a moderate to strong effect size.
#Text=A�p�greater than 0.05 would indicate the selective or full removal treatment failed to decrease the relative abundance or richness of EMF.
#Text=The probability of superiority (PS) was used to determine the effect size for species richness and relative abundance, where a probability of 0.5 indicates no effect (stochastic equality).
#Text=Additionally, probabilities between 0.6 and 1.0 indicate a moderate to strong effect of removal on decreasing EMF richness or relative abundance.
#Text=Conversely, probabilities between 0.0 and 0.4 indicate the opposite, where removal efforts could potentially lead to an increase in the richness or relative abundance of EMF.
#Text=Effect sizes ranging between 0.41 and 0.49 or 0.51 and 0.59, were considered small, indicating a minimal but observable effect of removal on EMF.
#Text=Subsequently, 95% confidence intervals (CI) for PS were derived from bootstrapping 1000 samples.

#Text=For paired Wilcoxon rank sum tests, the  stats package� was used, while the  vegan package� was used for Permutational Multivariate Analysis of Variance (PERMANOVA) tests, which assessed community composition (RStudio Team�2021).
#Text=All PERMANOVA tests were reported with the Stress Score and Analysis of Similarities (ANOSIM).
#Text=Selective Removal\rFirst, we analyzed the data from the selective removal treatment.
#Text=To test Hypothesis 1, we used a series of non-parametric tests to compare the richness or relative abundance of OTUs associated with EMF in either roots or soils.
#Text=Similarly, the tests for soils and roots were conducted individually.
#Text=For Hypothesis 1, the dependent variable was the diversity or relative abundance of mycorrhizal fungi, and the independent variable was treatment status ( before� or  after�).
#Text=A significant treatment status effect, where OTU richness and relative abundance declined significantly after selective removal, would support Hypothesis 1.
#Text=For Hypotheses 2, we conducted a series of PERMANOVAs to determine if any changes occurred to community composition after selective removal.
#Text=The dependent variable was the relative abundance of EMF or fungal OTUs.
#Text=The independent variable was timepoint (before vs. after).
#Text=Significant timepoint effects would support Hypothesis 2.
#Text=NMDS plots were used to illustrate community composition (McCune et al�2002).
#Text=To identify EMF OTUs that disproportionately contributed to any shifts in community composition after selective removal, we used the  indicspecies package� in RStudio (C�ceres & Legendre�2009).
#Text=Full Removal\rFor soil samples from the full removal treatment, we tested our hypotheses by using the same statistical tests as above, with one exception.
#Text=We did not test for changes in roots in the full removal treatment since no roots remained after the treatment (by design).\r.Results.
#Text=Metagenomic Data\rPE sequences yielded 7,982,887 total reads, with 5,087,201 reads meeting the minimum length for validation.
#Text=After filtering, a total of 4,900,942 reads were assigned taxonomy, producing 4061 OTUs.
#Text=The FUNGuild database identified 700 saprotrophs, 303 pathotroph_saprotroph_symbiotrophs, 261 symbiotrophs, 138 saprotrophs_symbiotrophs, 246 pathotrophs, and 78 pathotroph_symbiotrophs.
#Text=Soil samples were rarefied to 1901 sequences per sample, and root samples 9586 sequences per sample.
#Text=The most common taxa in the soil and root samples were from the order Hypocreales with an unidentified trophic mode.
#Text=The most abundant phylum in root and soil samples was Ascomycota, representing 69.3% of taxa found in soils and 65.8% in roots.
#Text=In soil samples, 29.9% of fungal taxa belonged to Basidiomycota, and 33.8% in roots.
#Text=Glomeromycota (AMF) represented less than 1% of the fungal taxa in soils and roots.

#Text=Selective Removal\rFollowing selective removal there was clear evidence that the richness of EMF in the arroyo willow soils decreased ( Fig�3A, one-sided�p�[decrease]  =  0.036, PS  =  0.642, 95% CI [0.512, 0.781]).
#Text=The relative abundance of EMF in soils also decreased from 17.6 to 9.44% following selective removal ( Fig�3B, one-sided�p�[decrease]  =  0.015, PS  =  0.673, 95% CI [0.662, 0.775]).

#Text=With respect to roots, there was clear evidence demonstrating the richness of EMF decreased following selective removal ( Fig�3C, one sided�p�[decrease]  =  0.030, PS  =  0.672, 95% CI [0.521, 0.833]), mirroring the shift in the richness and relative abundance of EMF in soils.
#Text=However, the evidence for a decrease in the relative abundance of EMF on roots was less conclusive ( Fig�3D, one-sided�p�[decrease]  =  0.117, PS  =  0.610, 95% CI [0.607, 0.701]).
#Text=Here, the moderate PS indicates a potential effect of selective removal on the relative abundance of arroyo willows roots without being substantiated by the�p�value.

#Text=However, all other�p�values and the corresponding effect sizes, which ranged from 0.6 to 1.0, supported our prediction that selective removal would decrease the richness and relative abundance of EMF.
#Text=Figure 3\r \rRichness (A) and relative abundance (B) of operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of ectomycorrhizal fungi in soils from the selective removal treatment.
#Text=Richness (C) and relative abundance (D) of operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of ectomycorrhizal fungi in the roots of the selective removal treatment.
#Text=Box plots denote the interquartile range between the 25 and 75 percentiles (boxes), medians (black lines), and potential outliers (dots).
#Text=Single asterisks (*) indicate significant differences at the�p�< 0.05 level as determined by the one-sided Wilcoxon rank sum test predicting a decrease.

#Text=Following selective removal, the community composition of broader fungi in arroyo willow soils shifted, owing to an increase in variation among samples ( Fig�4A,�p  =  0.047, stress  =  0.152, ANOSIM  =  0.030).

#Text=Yet, when we focused on the community composition of EMF specifically, there was no clear evidence of community change following selective removal ( Fig�4B,�p  =  0.762, stress  =  0.190, ANOSIM  =  0.021).

#Text=Within arroyo willow roots, selective removal altered the community composition of broader fungi ( Fig�4C,�p  =  0.001, stress  =  0.223, ANOSIM  =  0.068) but not EMF ( Fig�4D,�p  =  0.241, stress  =  0.241, ANOSIM  =  0.043).

#Text=Figure 4\r \rNonmetric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) plots of the community composition of the broader fungal community in soils (A), the ectomycorrhizal community in soils (B), the broader fungal community in roots (C), and the ectomycorrhizal community in roots (D) associated with arroyo willows in the selective removal treatment.
#Text=Symbols  =  samples.

#Text=Single asterisks (*) denote significant differences at the�p�< 0.05 level between treatments as determined by a PERMANOVA test, while double asterisks (**) indicate significant differences at the�p�< 0.01 level.
#Text=Solid or dashed lines  =  97% confidence intervals.
#Text=In soils, the EMF taxa�Pulvinula�sp. 1 (p  =  0.015),�Anguillospora�sp.
#Text=(p  =  0.039), and�Tomentellasp. 2 (p  =  0.0004) were indicators of the time period before selective removal, compared to after selective removal ( Fig�5A).
#Text=Similarly, roots of arroyo willow were associated with three EMF indicator taxa.
#Text=�Pulvinula�sp. 1 decreased following selective removal (p  =  0.015), while�Tomentella�sp. 3 (p  =  0.038) and�Tomentella clavigera�sp. 2 (p  =  0.039) increased ( Fig�5B).

#Text=Figure 5\r \rThe relative abundance of the 15 most common operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of ectomycorrhizal fungi in arroyo willow soils (A) and roots (B) in the selective removal treatment.
#Text=Bar plots depict means  +/-  SE.

#Text=Single asterisks (*) denote significant indicator species at the�p  <  0.05 level before versus after selective removal, while triple asterisks (***) denote significant indicator species at the�p�< 0.001 level before versus after selective removal.

#Text=Full Removal\rContrary to our initial prediction that full removal would decrease EMF, the richness of EMF in Brazilian pepper tree soils increased following full removal ( Fig�6A one-sided�p[decrease]  =  0.997, PS  =  0.268, 95% CI [0.133, 0.427]).
#Text=Similarly, there was evidence that the relative abundance of EMF rose following the full removal treatment ( Fig�6B one-sided�p[decrease]  =  0.973, PS  =  0.335, 95% CI [0.325, 0.401]).
#Text=Evidence for the increase is based on the PS for the relative abundance and richness of EMF being less than 0.5.
#Text=Figure 6\r \rRichness (A) and relative abundance (B) of operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of mycorrhizal fungi in soils of the full removal treatment.
#Text=Box plots denote the interquartile range between the 25 and 75 percentiles (boxes), medians (black lines), and potential outliers (dots).
#Text=After the full removal of Brazilian pepper tree, the composition of the broader fungal community changed in soils ( Fig�7A,�p  =  0.024, stress  =  0.161, ANOSIM  =  0.042).
#Text=Specifically, variation among samples decreased.
#Text=This shift was not reflected in the soil EMF community ( Fig�7B,�p  =  0.667, stress  =  0.132, ANOSIM  =  0.149).
#Text=The EMF taxa�Geopora�sp. 2 (p  =  0.009) and�Geopora�sp. 4 (p  =  0.009) were indicators of the time after full removal, with their relative abundance increasing ( Fig�8).

#Text=Figure 7\r \rNonmetric multidimensional scaling (NMDS) plots of the community composition of the broader fungal community (A) and the ectomycorrhizal community in soils associated with Brazilian pepper tree in the full removal treatment (B).
#Text=Symbols  =  samples.
#Text=Single asterisks (*) denote significant differences resulting from a PERMANOVA test at the�p�< 0.05 level.
#Text=Solid or dashed lines  =  97% confidence intervals.
#Text=Figure 8\r \rThe relative abundance of the 15 most common operational taxonomic units (OTUs) of ectomycorrhizal fungi in Brazilian pepper tree soils in the full removal treatment.
#Text=Bar plots depict means  +/-  SE.
#Text=Double asterisks (**) denote significant indicator species at the�p  <  0.01 level�before versus after selective removal.
#Text=Discussion.
#Text=Our study is the first we know of to examine EMF recovery following Brazilian Pepper removal, although a previous study followed AMF recovery after removal in Florida (Aziz et al�1995).
#Text=Surprisingly, we observed an increase in the richness and relative abundance of EMF in the soil after full removal, which entailed complete tree removal along with the top 60  cm of soil.
#Text=This was likely caused by soil amendments but not commercial inoculation.
#Text=In other respects, EMF responded as expected.
#Text=For instance, selective removal decreased the relative abundance and richness of EMF in soils.
#Text=For willow roots, selective removal only led to a decline in EMF species richness, while relative abundance was unaffected.
#Text=Moreover, while EMF composition did not change, the composition of the broader fungal community shifted following selective and full removal.
#Text=Despite the intention to protect native arroyo willows from disturbances associated with the application of soil amendments, this approach led to a decline in EMF.

#Text=Our finding that commercial soil inoculation did not shift the community composition of EMF corroborates with previous studies that show a commercial inoculum is ineffective compared to a reference product (Maltz & Treseder�2015).
#Text=Our results suggest that the organic soil amendments might have facilitated the increase in EMF richness after full removal.
#Text=A combination of chitin, humic acid, and compost was applied to the full removal site.
#Text=The compost was not sterile, so it could have contained EMF (Pagliarani et al�2023).
#Text=In addition, humic acid stimulates the growth of mycelium in EMF (Hr  elov� et al�2007).
#Text=These organic amendments might have likewise contributed to the increase in EMF richness after full removal.
#Text=Without the organic soil amendments, the full removal effort may have led to a decline in EMF, as demonstrated by the decrease in EMF associated with the selective removal effort.
#Text=The relative abundance of the EMF indicator species,�Geopora� spp, increased after the complete removal of the Brazilian pepper tree.
#Text=In other ecosystems,�Geopora�can maintain a presence in soils despite the loss of plant hosts (Mueller et al�2019; Shemesh et al�2020).
#Text=�Geopora�are known to occupy willow stands, including those in degraded or contaminated landscapes (Bell et al�2015; Hrynkiewicz et al�2015; Querejeta et al�2021).
#Text=As arroyo willows in the restored riparian corridor mature, infection by�Geopora� spp is more likely.
#Text=Therefore, the full removal effort may benefit arroyo willows by the increases in the relative abundance of�Geopora.

#Text=Our study builds on the few previous studies that have identified mycorrhizal taxa associated with native willows in Southern California (Allen et al�2000; Querejeta et al�2009; Taniguchi et al�2018).
#Text=The fungal taxa associated with arroyo willows in our study have also been identified in willow habitats outside of the region.
#Text=In willow forests contaminated by mine tailings,�Pulvinula� spp can reduce abiotic stress induced by heavy metals (Kola  �kov� et al�2017; Cao et al�2020).
#Text=However, a�Pulvinula�taxon declined following selective removal in Big Canyon.
#Text=Additionally,�Tomentella� spp alleviates abiotic stress associated with high salinity (Hrynkiewicz et al�2015).
#Text=In our case, one�Tomentella�taxon increased, and two others declined with selective removal.
#Text=The soil at Big Canyon has elevated levels of salinity and heavy metals (ESA�2016).
#Text=If�Pulvinula�and�Tomentella�also diminish salinity and heavy metal stress in arroyo willow, the reduction in�Pulvinula�and two�Tomentella�taxa may be disadvantageous to arroyo willow recovery.
#Text=When attempting to remove invasive species, widespread disturbance can hinder the long-term recovery of native plant species (Prior et al�2018).
#Text=Ideally, removing invasive plants before they become widely established is the most effective approach to minimize disturbance.
#Text=However, many riparian communities in the western United States are extensively invaded, increasing the need for high-disturbance removal (Goodwin et al�1997; USGS�2002; Boland�2016).
#Text=In cases where significant disturbance cannot be avoided, the application of inocula should be considered to re-establish mycorrhizal fungi.
#Text=Yet, commercial inocula are typically ineffective in restoration efforts (Maltz & Treseder�2015), as we found here.

#Text=Instead, practitioners might consider using inoculum from a local reference ecosystem, because this approach more often improves mycorrhizal colonization and benefits native plants (Hrynkiewicz et al�2009; Maltz & Treseder�2015).
#Text=Due to the lack of riparian forests that are uninvaded by Brazilian pepper tree in Big Canyon, our study did not include monotypic stands of arroyo willow.
#Text=Instead, we focused on willow trees retained during selective removal.

#Text=However, examining the EMF associated with monotypic stands of arroyo willows can provide a potential reservoir to develop a reference inoculum for the existing willows in selective removal and the newly established willows in full removal.
#Text=While the goal of our study was to examine the immediate effects of restoration, long-term sampling can determine if EMF richness recovers in selective removal over time.
#Text=In similar restoration projects, willow trees have taken 1�3  years to reach conditions resembling pre-invasion states (Sher et al�2018; Goetz et al�2022).
#Text=Our study provides a baseline for future studies such as this.
#Text=Although the removal of invasive plant species is an essential step in riparian forest restoration, we may improve outcomes by considering effects on mycorrhizal fungi.
#Text=Our study yielded unexpected results, such as an increase in EMF richness following the full removal of the Brazilian pepper tree, possibly owing to organic soil amendments.
#Text=In contrast, selective removal led to a decline in the relative abundance of EMF where a soil amendment was not applied.
#Text=Using local reference inocula and organic soil amendments to augment mycorrhizal fungi may mitigate deleterious effects like these on the mycorrhizal community.

#Text=In particular, we advocate for the use of a local reference inoculum instead of a commercial inoculum, since our results failed to detect the presence of any EMF associated with the commercial inoculum.
#Text=Additionally, an organic soil amendment may also stimulate EMF following removal efforts.
#Text=These findings emphasize the importance of considering relationships between invasive species, mycorrhizal fungi, and native plants to ensure the successful restoration of riparian ecosystems.
